Chlorine-doped α-Co(OH)2 hollow nanododecahedrons prepared by a ZIF-67 selfsacrificing template route and enhanced OER catalytic activity†
Qingqing Zha, Wenyan Xu, Xiaolei Li and Yonghong Ni *
Hollow α-Co(OH)2 and Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2 nano-dodecahedrons were successfully synthesized via a ZIF-67-assisted template route in the absence/presence of NaCl. The reactions were carried out in a
Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave at 40 °C for 4 h, employing dodecahedral ZIF-67 and hexamethyl-
enetetramine (HMT) as the reactants. The as-obtained hollow nano-dodecahedrons were characterized
by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM), transmission
electron microscopy (TEM), Fourier transform infrared (FTIR), X-ray photoelectron energy, EDS mapping and N2 sorption–desorption technologies. Electrochemical measurements showed that both α-Co(OH)2 and Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2 hollow nano-dodecahedrons displayed excellent catalytic activities for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2 hollow ones possessed stronger electrocatalytic performances. To deliver a current density of 10 mA cm−2, Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2 hollow nanododecahedrons required a low overpotential of 298 mV, which is smaller than most reported α-Co(OH)2 catalysts. Also, the as-obtained hollow catalyst still had excellent OER cycling stability and durability. After
1000 CV cycles, the overpotential merely slightly increased. Continuously catalyzing at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 for 40 h, the voltage only increased ∼2.5%.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Owing to the intensifying global energy crisis and environmental problems, developing clean energy sources is urgent. Now, several clean energy sources are drawing much attention, including solar energy, wind energy, and nuclear energy. However, the storage of energy in a sustainable manner is the main hurdle preventing the uptake of the above renewable energy technologies.1,2 Besides increasing the battery space, at present, electrochemical water splitting to produce H2 and O2 is another very attractive way to store electricity generated from the above renewable energy sources. Nonetheless, as a semireaction of electrochemical water splitting, the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) has slow kinetics. Therefore, an effective catalyst is usually required to accelerate the OER process.1 IrO2 and RuO2 have exhibited excellent electrocatalytic activity for
the OER to date, but their wide use is limited because of low earth content and high cost.2 Thus, non-noble-metal electrocatalysts with low cost and outstanding electrocatalytic properties are becoming a study focus in chemistry, materials and energy sciences.
As a transition metal, cobalt is located in the eighth group with Ru and Ir in the periodic table. Hence, cobalt compounds should have similar electrocatalytic activity with Ru and Ir for OER. In fact, many cobalt-based materials have stood out, such as oxides, hydroxides, sulfides, and phosphides.3–6 In particular, Co(OH)2 with layered structures is paid a lot of attention because of its low water oxidation potential and electrochemical stability for OER under alkaline conditions. A number of investigations have proven that the typical shape of layered Co(OH)2 is sheet- or plate-like structures, which should derive from its layered nature.7 For instance, Zhang et al. employed 2-methylimidazole as the base source and etching reagent to prepare ultrathin α-Co(OH)2 nanomeshes with 3 nm thickness through a simple room-temperature route. The asobtained nanomeshes presented a current density of 10 mA cm−2 with an overpotential of 303 mV.8 Employing a similar room-temperature precipitation route, Liang and coworkers fabricated ultrathin α-Co(OH)2 nanosheets (2.5 nm) and OER tests showed that an overpotential of 267 mV was †Electronic supplementary information (ESI) available. required to deliver a current density of 10 mA cm−2.9 However, sheet- or plate-like structures are easily stacked, which reduces surface active sites during catalysis. To keep the surface active sites, some three dimensional (3D) structures constructed by ultrathin α-Co(OH)2 nanosheets were also synthesized.10,11 For example, Kim and coworkers designed a facile room-temperature precipitation route to synthesize ultrathin amorphous α-Co(OH)2 nanosheets grown on Ag nanowire surfaces using NaBH4 as the base source and the as-obtained 3D superstructures exhibited improved OER catalytic activity.10
Many studies have discovered that these hollow micro/ nanostructures could reduce internal resistance and improve power capability due to large surface areas and short diffusion paths for ions and electrons.12–14 However, few hollow α-Co(OH)2 micro/nanostructures are reported in the literature for OER research to date.15 In the present work, a self-sacrificing template strategy was designed for synthesis of α-Co(OH)2 hollow nano-dodecahedrons employing ZIF-67 dodecahedrons and hexamethylenetetramine (HMT) as the reactants. Experiments showed that the as-obtained α-Co(OH)2 hollow nano-dodecahedrons presented excellent OER catalytic activity. More importantly, Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2 hollow nano-dodecahedrons could also be obtained from a system with Cl− ions under the same synthesis conditions. The as-obtained Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2 hollow nano-dodecahedrons exhibited better OER activities than α-Co(OH)2 ones. Moreover, compared with hollow α-Co(OH)2 nanoflowers prepared by a Cu2O hard template route with the assistance of PVP,15 and Cl-doped 2D α-Co(OH)2 nanosheets electrochemically deposited on carbon cloth,16 the present α-Co(OH)2 and Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2 hollow nano-dodecahedrons both showed better electrocatalytic activity for OER.

sections.heading: 2. Experimental section
sections.text: All reagents and chemicals were analytically pure, bought from Shanghai Chemical Company, and used without further purification. Deionized water was used throughout the experiments.

sections.heading: 2.1 Synthesis of α-Co(OH)2 and Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2 hollow nano-dodecahedrons
sections.text:
To prepare α-Co(OH)2 and Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2 hollow nanododecahedrons, ZIF-67 with dodecahedrons were obtained in advance according to the reported method in ref. 17 with some modifications. Typically, 1.43 g (∼4.91 mmol) of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and 3.24 g (∼39.5 mmol) of 2-methylimidazole were dissolved in 100 mL methanol, respectively. These two solutions were then mixed under magnetic stirring for 2 h at room temperature. The solid product was collected by centrifugation, washed with methanol several times, and vacuum dried at 60 °C.
Subsequently, 20 mg ZIF-67 and 150 mg hexamethylenetetramine (HMT) were added to a 30 mL water–methanol mixed solvent with the volume ratio of 9 : 1 in the absence/presence of 50 mg NaCl. After the as-obtained mixture was stirred for 5 min, the system was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and thermally treated at 40 °C for 4 h. Then, the system was cooled to room temperature naturally. Green precipitates were collected and washed with deionized water and ethanol several times, then dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C. The detailed formation processes and the electrochemical oxidation performances of α-Co(OH)2 and Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2 hollow nano-dodecahedrons are illustrated in Scheme 1.

sections.heading: 2.2 Characterization
sections.text:
X-ray powder diffraction patterns of the precursor and final products were collected from a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154060 nm) at a scanning rate of 0.2° s−1 and 2θ in the range from 10° to 80°. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) of the product was conducted using a Thermo ESCALAB 250 instrument with monochromic Al Kα (hν = 1486.6 eV) and at the power of 150 W. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were obtained on a Shimadzu FTIR-8400S spectrometer by pressing a small amount of sample and KBr crystals into a plate. Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms were measured at liquid nitrogen temperature (77 K), using a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 analyzer. Surface areas were calculated by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method.

For EDX analyses, the samples were stuck directly on a conductive tape. sections.heading: 2.3 Electrochemical measurements
sections.text:
A CHI660E electrochemical station with a three-electrode cell was employed for electrochemical measurements. Catalyst suspensions composed of 0.5 mL water, 0.45 mL ethanol, 4 mg catalyst and 0.05 mL Nafion solution (5%) were ultrasonically dispersed for about 30 min to form uniform ink. Then, 4 μL of suspension was dropped onto a polished glassy carbon electrode (GCE) with 3 mm in diameter. After drying, GCE with a loading amount of 0.225 mg cm−2 was used as the working electrode. A Pt wire and saturated calomel electrode (SCE) were separately used as the counter electrode and the reference electrode with 1 M KOH solution as the electrolyte. Before testing, the KOH solution was purged with O2 for 30 min and simultaneously catalysts were activated through 10 cyclic voltammetry (CV) cycles in a range from 1.067 to 1.767 V (vs. RHE) at a scan rate of 100 mV s−1. All linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves were corrected with 95% iR compensations and scanned at a rate of 2 mV s−1. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) of the catalyst in a frequency range of 100 000–0.01 Hz was performed at 1.56 V (vs. RHE) with an amplitude of the sinusoidal voltage at 5 mV. The stability test was measured by covering the catalysts on carbon cloth (CC, 1 cm × 1 cm) without iR compensation. To obtain the electrochemical active surface area (ECSA), the CV curves were measured in CH3CN with 0.15 M KPF6 in a narrow potential range (±50 mV) centered on the open circuit potential (OCP) at scan rates of 15, 20, 25, 30 and 35 mV s−1, respectively.18,19 Then, a straight line was plotted with the difference between janode and jcathode (Δj = ja − jc) of each CV cycle with OCP vs. the scan rate. Since the slope of the line was 2 times as large as the electrochemical double layer capacitance (Cdl), the Cdl
value was estimated. The ECSA could be calculated according to the following equation: ECSA = Cdl/Cs, where Cs was the specific capacitance of a flat smooth surface of the electrode material, about 11 μF cm−2 according to the literature.18
In the present experiments, overpotentials (η) were calibrated with respect to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) according to the formula: η = ESCE + 0.0591 pH + 0.24 V − 1.23 V. The turnover frequency (TOF) value was calculated based on the current density from the eqn (1):
TOF ¼ ðj SÞ=ð4 n FÞ ð1Þ where j is the measured current density at a given overpotential, S is the surface area of the electrode (0.071 cm2 for the GCE), 4 is the number of electrons transferred during O2 production, n is the mole number of metal ions on the electrode and F is the Faraday constant (F = 96 485 C mol−1). All the Co atoms were assumed to be accessible for catalyzing the OER.

sections.heading: 3.1 Morphology and structure characterization
sections.text:
Some studies have discovered that ZIF-67 can release Co2+ ions in a water-containing system due to the coordination-dissociation equilibrium.20,21 When certain anions exist in the system, such as OH− ions, released Co2+ ions will react with them to produce a precipitate on the surface of ZIF-67. The exhaustion of Co2+ ions will break the coordination-dissociation equilibrium of ZIF-67, which results in the release of more Co2+ ions; thus, a precipitate is continuously produced. Finally, new matter with hollow structures can be formed.21 The above process is called as the Kirkendall effect. Based on the above thought, we anticipated synthesizing the target product with specific morphology in this work.
Fig. 1a exhibits a typical FESEM image of the precursor ZIF-67, from which many dodecahedrons with smooth surfaces can be readily found. XRD analysis confirmed that the as-obtained dodecahedrons were indeed ZIF-67 (see Fig. 1b). After ZIF-67 dodecahedrons had been placed into the mixed solvent of water–methanol with HMT in the absence/presence of NaCl at 40 °C for 4 h, the as-obtained final products still maintained the outlines of the precursor (see Fig. S1†). Further enlargements uncovered however, that the final products actually lost the regular shape of the precursor due to the formation of hollow structures. Also, the surfaces became rough (see Fig. 2). The hollow structures of the final products were confirmed by TEM technology. Fig. 3a depicts a low-magnification TEM image of the product prepared from the system with NaCl and hollow structures can be readily seen. Moreover, Fig. 3b exhibits an enlarged TEM image of a single hollow structure, from which the outline of a dodecahedron can be dimly identified. To further prove the hollow structures of the final products, EDS mapping analyses were also investigated. As seen from Fig. 3c, a dark field image clearly displays the hollow structure of the final product. Also, the distributions of Co, O and Cl elements in the edge are more compact than those in the center. Furthermore, the appearance of Cl element implies the successful integration of Cl− into α-Co(OH)2.
Fig. S2† compares XRD patterns and IR spectra of the asprepared α-Co(OH)2 and Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2. As seen from
Fig. S2a,† two samples present similar diffraction pattern, implying that the integration of Cl− ions into α-Co(OH)2 did not alter the phase of α-Co(OH)2. Against the strong diffraction peaks of the precursor, the final products have very weak diffraction intensities, implying their poor crystallinity. According to papers reported by Liang9 and Tang,22 several major diffraction peaks can be indexed to the (003), (006), (012) and (110) planes of an α-Co(OH)2 phase. Moreover, these two samples also exhibit similar FTIR spectra (see Fig. S2b†). The strong and broad peak centered at 3450 cm−1 is due to the O–H stretching vibration modes of interlayer water molecules and H-bound OH groups. The signal at 1637 cm−1 in the vibration spectroscopy is due to the bending vibration of hydroxyl groups.23 The peak at 1057 cm−1 results from Co–O–H bond stretching vibrations, and the peaks at 621 and 520 cm−1 are associated with Co–O bending vibrations.11,24 Furthermore, a peak at 1467 cm−1 should come from the residual of HMT. Another peak at 1380 cm−1 in α-Co(OH)2 should be attributed to NO3
− ions,25 and in Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2 it shifts to 1366 cm−1. This shift phenomenon could be caused by the integration of Cl− ions. Obviously, the above XRD and IR ana-

Fig. S3† compares N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms and BJH pore size distributions of α-Co(OH)2 and Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2. Both present similar type-IV isotherms, and the hysteresis loops of type H3 at the relative P/P0 range of 0.5–1.0 indicate the presence of porous channels.26,27 Nonetheless, the integration of Cl− into α-Co(OH)2 slightly increased the BET surface area and BJH pore volume of α-Co(OH)2, which is favorable for improving electrocatalytic performances.
It is worth pointing out that the integrated amount of Cl in α-Co(OH)2 can be affected by the original NaCl amount. Fig. S4† exhibits EDS analyses of the samples obtained from the systems with original NaCl amounts of 30, 50, 100 and 200 mg, respectively, under the same experimental conditions. One can clearly find that the Cl/Co atomic ratio increases from 1 : 31.2 to 1 : 19.2 when the original NaCl amount increased from 30 mg to 50 mg. Subsequently, when continuously adding amounts of NaCl, the Cl/Co atomic ratio had no marked change, and approximately equals 1 : 19. The above fact implies that the content of Cl in the catalyst cannot be
continuously added. Since the product prepared from the system with 50 mg of NaCl possesses better catalytic activity than that prepared from system with 30 mg of NaCl (see Fig. S5†), we selected the product prepared from the system with 50 mg of NaCl as the catalyst in the present work.

sections.heading: 3.2 OER catalytic performance
sections.text:
To investigate the OER electrocatalytic activity of as-prepared hollow nano-dodecahedrons, a typical three-electrode setup was utilized with 1 M KOH solution as the electrolyte. Before the OER test, the catalysts were activated by ten CV cycles at 100 mV s−1. As shown in Fig. 4a, only a strong anodic peak appeared in the first CV cycle of Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2/GCE. Subsequently, the CV curves from the second to the tenth cycle almost overlap, implying that a stable electrode was reached. The above phenomena should be attributed to the irreversible oxidation of Co(OH)2 to CoOOH.
28,29 To confirm the above oxidation, we investigated the composition and phase of the catalyst after the first CV activation through EDS and XRD technologies. As shown in Fig. S6a,† the EDS analysis proved that the atomic ratio of Cl/Co decreased to 1 : 183.4, implying the loss

Fig. 4b displays the LSV curves of the as-synthesized ZIF-67 nano-dodecahedrons, hollow α-Co(OH)2, hollow Cldoped α-Co(OH)2 and commercial IrO2 catalysts. To reach a current density of 10 mA cm−2, various catalysts in turn require an overpotential of 407 mV for ZIF-67, 369 mV for IrO2, 306 mV for α-Co(OH)2 and 298 mV for Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2. Markedly, hollow α-Co(OH)2 and Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2 catalysts exhibited enhanced electrocatalytic activity; and the integration of Cl− ions further improved the catalytic activity of hollow α-Co(OH)2. To study the OER catalytic kinetics of various electrodes, the linear parts of the above LSV curves were fitted by the following Tafel formula: η = a + b log j where, η and j stand for the overpotential and the current density, respectively, b is the Tafel slope and a is the cathodic intercept that is related to the exchange current density.30,31 As seen from Fig. 4c, the Tafel slopes of various electrodes are 86.3 mV dec−1 for ZIF-67/GCE, 70.3 mV dec−1 for IrO2/GCE, 65.8 mV dec −1 for α-Co(OH)2/GCE, and 57 mV dec−1 for Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2/ GCE. Obviously, the Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2/GCE has the smallest Tafel slope in various electrodes. Since a low Tafel slope implies a fast discharge OER process,32,33 the present Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2/GCE has the most favorable OER kinetics. In addition, Fig. 4d compares the current densities of various electrodes at the potential of 1.6 V (vs. RHE). The Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2/GCE exhibits a current density of 110.7 mA cm−2, which is much higher than α-Co(OH)2/GCE (49.4 mA cm−2) and ZIF-67/GCE (3.39 mA cm−2). Simultaneously, to further evaluate the electrocatalytic performances of various catalysts, the turnover frequencies (TOFs) at the overpotential of 300 mV were also obtained according to eqn (1), assuming that all cobalt atoms in the catalysts contributed to the reaction and Faraday efficiency was 100%.19,31 The corresponding TOFs are displayed in Fig. 4e. Cl-Doped α-Co(OH)2, α-Co(OH)2 and ZIF-67 in turn have TOFs of 0.0152, 0.00930 and 0.00126 s−1. The above results clearly testify that Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2 nanododecahedrons have the best electrocatalytic activity. Further investigations revealed that the as-obtained Cldoped α-Co(OH)2/GCE possessed good cycle stability. As shown in Fig. 5a, there was a very small deviation between LSV curves of the electrode before and after 1000 cycles, implying a slight increase of overpotential at the same current density. Moreover, Fig. 5b depicts the chronopotentiometry curve (without iR correction) of the as-obtained Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2/ GCE electrode at a current density of 10 mA cm−2. After continuously catalyzing for 40 h in 1.0 M KOH solution, no obvious voltage change could be found, indicating that the present electrode also had good long-term stability. To evaluate interface reactions and electrode kinetics, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) analyses of the above Co-based electrocatalysts were investigated. In the Nyquist plots shown in Fig. 5c, the order of the semicircle diameters for three catalysts from small to large are Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2, α-Co(OH)2 and ZIF-67, indicating an increasing

Here, Rct is related to the electrocatalytic kinetics. A small Rct value is favorable for electron transport between the electrode and electrolyte. Obviously, Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2 hollow nano-dodecahedrons possess the strongest electrocatalytic activity.
Electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) is another important parameter used to evaluate catalytic activity of a catalyst. A large ECSA generally has more active sites and is also favorable for dissipation of gas bubbles. To clearly reflect electrocatalytic activity of the Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2 catalyst, we investigated the ECSA change of the Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2/GCE electrode before and after continuously catalyzing for 40 h. As controls, the ECSA change of the α-Co(OH)2/GCE electrode before and after continuous catalysis was also studied. Fig. S7† displays the CV curves of various electrodes in the potential window of a narrow range (±50 mV) centered at the open circuit potential in CH3CN with 0.15 M KPF6 at scan rates of 15, 20, 25, 30 and 35 mV s−1, respectively. A linear relation between scan rate and the Δj value at open circuit potential was obtained from a single CV cycle at every scan rate (see Fig. 5d). Before catalysis, the Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2/GCE and α-Co(OH)2/GCE electrodes possessed approximate Cdl values of 0.062 and 0.063 mF cm−2 in turn. After catalyzing for 40 h, the corresponding Cdl value was separately 2.67 and 2.25 mF cm
−2. Table S1† lists the Cdl and the ECSA values of as-prepared Co (OH)2 catalysts before and after continuously catalyzing for 40 h. One can clearly see that the ECSA value of CoOOH transformed from α-Co(OH)2 is 204.5 and the one of defect CoOOH from Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2 is 242.7. According to the equation AElect = AGeom × ECSA (AGeom = 0.071 cm
2),36 the AElect values of defect CoOOH and CoOOH are 17.23 and 14.52 cm2, respectively. To accurately reflect the catalytic activity of the present catalyst here, the polarization curves of the Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2/GCE and α-Co(OH)2/GCE electrodes were normalized with ECSA.36 As seen in Fig. 6, the Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2 still presents the stronger OER catalytic activity than α-Co(OH)2, which is in good agreement with the result shown in Fig. 2b. In Fig. S6a,† EDS analysis had proven the loss of Cl content after the first CV activation. To further ascertain the change of Cl content in the catalyst before and after OER measurement in 1 M KOH solution, Fig. 7 compares EDS results of Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2 catalyst before and after OER measurements. Before the OER test, the Cl element can be readily seen in the catalyst besides O and Co elements. However, the Cl peak disappeared after OER measurement. This fact confirmed that Cl atoms were etched during the OER test, which caused formation of the defect in the α-Co(OH)2 hollow nano-dodecahedrons. Compared with a perfect hollow structure, the α-Co(OH)2 with defect provided a larger ECSA.16,37 As a result, the Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2 catalyst presents better electrocatalytic activity. Meanwhile, XPS technology was also employed for analyzing the composition change of the Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2 catalyst before and after the OER test in 1 M KOH solution. As shown in Fig. 8a, peaks belonging to Co, O and Cl elements are clearly visible in the survey spectrum of the catalyst before the OER test. In the high resolution spectrum of Co 2p (Fig. 8b), the distance between Co 2p1/2 centered at 796.6 eV and Co 2p3/2 at 780.6 eV is 16 eV, which is convincing evidence of the existence of Co2+ in Co(OH)2.
38 Simultaneously, the corresponding satellite peaks at 802.4 and 786.2 eV, respectively, further confirm the oxidation state of Co2+.39 Furthermore, the peak at 782.5 eV should correspond to a Co–Cl bond.29,36 The O 1s spectrum is very simple. As seen from Fig. 8c, the strong O peak at 531 eV is ascribed to the O 1s spin–orbit of Co (OH)2.
29,31 In the Cl 2p spectrum (Fig. 8d), two peaks at 197.3 and 198.8 eV are attributed to Cl 2p3/2 and Cl 2p1/2, respectively.40 After an OER test, the Cl peak disappeared in the survey spectrum (see Fig. 8e). At the same time, the appearance of the F 1s peak in the XPS survey spectrum should derive from Nafion molecules added during preparation of the working electrode. Meanwhile, the peaks of Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 separately shift to 780.1 and 795.2 eV. The corresponding satellite peaks are in turn 781.3, 790.1 and 796.4, 805.2 eV and their distances reduced to 15.1 eV, which corresponds to Co3+
(see Fig. 8f).41 Also, the O 1s spectrum obviously varied

As shown in Fig. 8g, the peak at 531.1 eV comes from the bond of O–H,38 and a marked peak appeared at 529.6 eV, which is associated with the covalent bond of Co–O after the formation of CoOOH.42,43 More importantly, no obvious signal of the Cl element can be detected in Fig. 8h, implying the loss of Cl after OER; this is consistent with the results of EDS analysis.
It has been found that atomic level defects can promote electrocatalytic performance.44,45 In the present work, the doped Cl atoms could be easily etched under the electrochemical conditions.46 Thus, vacancies and defects could be introduced which improved the electrocatalytic performances of α-Co(OH)2 hollow nano-dodecahedrons. Furthermore, Fig. S8† depicts a FESEM image (a) and XRD pattern (b) of Cldoped α-Co(OH)2 catalyst after continuously catalyzing 40 h in
1 M KOH solution at a current density of 10 mA cm−2. One can readily see that the morphology of the catalyst was well maintained (Fig. S8a†), which should be the main reason that the catalyst has good durability. The XRD analysis shown in Fig. S8b† uncovered the formation of CoOOH. Combining the above XRD result with that in Fig. S6b,† one can easily conclude that the catalyst with outstanding electrocatalytic performances should be CoOOH.
To further estimate OER activity of the present Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2 catalyst, Table 1 compares the overpotentials and Tafel slopes of several Co(OH)2 catalysts. Our catalyst presents a close or smaller overpotential and Tafel slope, implying its excellent OER catalytic activity.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In summary, Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2 hollow nano-dodecahedrons were successfully synthesized by a mild solution route at 40 °C for 4 h, employing dodecahedral ZIF-67 as a self-sacrificing template in the presence of NaCl and HMT. Formation of hollow nano-dodecahedrons should be attributed to the Kirkendall effect. Experiments showed that the integration of Cl element into α-Co(OH)2 hollow nano-dodecahedrons did not change the morphology of α-Co(OH)2, but could markedly promote electrocatalytic activity for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER). To deliver a current density of 10 mA cm−2, Cldoped α-Co(OH)2 hollow nano-dodecahedrons required a low overpotential of 298 mV, which was smaller than α-Co(OH)2 without Cl. Further investigations revealed that the excellent OER activity should be ascribed to the production of defects in the catalyst due to the etching of Cl in the OER. metadata.abstractText: Hollow α-Co(OH)2 and Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2 nano-dodecahedrons were successfully synthesized via a ZIF-67-assisted template route in the absence/presence of NaCl. The reactions were carried out in a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave at 40 °C for 4 h, employing dodecahedral ZIF-67 and hexamethylenetetramine (HMT) as the reactants. The as-obtained hollow nano-dodecahedrons were characterized by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), Fourier transform infrared (FTIR), X-ray photoelectron energy, EDS mapping and N2 sorption–desorption technologies. Electrochemical measurements showed that both α-Co(OH)2 and Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2 hollow nano-dodecahedrons displayed excellent catalytic activities for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2 hollow ones possessed stronger electrocatalytic performances. To deliver a current density of 10 mA cm, Cl-doped α-Co(OH)2 hollow nanododecahedrons required a low overpotential of 298 mV, which is smaller than most reported α-Co(OH)2 catalysts. Also, the as-obtained hollow catalyst still had excellent OER cycling stability and durability. After 1000 CV cycles, the overpotential merely slightly increased. Continuously catalyzing at the current density of 10 mA cm for 40 h, the voltage only increased ∼2.5%.
